content:
Click the 3-bar menu icon in the upper right, New Account, Email, enter your credentials, then click Manual config. and enter these settings:

incoming POP server: mail.zianet.com, port 110, security = none, authentication = password, transmitted insecurely, User Name = part of address before @

outgoing SMTP server: mail.zianet.com, port 587, security = none, authentication = password, transmitted insecurely, User Name = part of address before @

https://w3.zianet.com/mozilla-thunderbird-e-mail-setup.html

content:
1. Over half of your space usage is in the "All Mail" folder, whose messages don't actually get deleted unless you manually go into that folder and delete them. (I find that deleting them using gmail web is most effective)

2. You don't need to be subscribed to the "All Mail" folder in Thunderbird, which will save you considerable disk space.

3. On the off chance that you have lingering files from old compacts, look for files with nstmp in the file name.
creator: wsmwk

content:
Thanks for reply Wayne.

1/. Don't quite understande what your saying re "All Mail" folder. I assumed this was basically the "Inbox" folder, and that if I deleted all the mails in the "All Mail" folder they would disappear from Inbox also?

2/. Also don't understand what you mean by 'subscribed' to All Mail folder - so far as I remember this was the default folder setup when first installed TB
creator: monsoonhoy

content:
Peter Hoy said
Thanks for reply Wayne. 1/. Don't quite understande what your saying re "All Mail" folder. I assumed this was basically the "Inbox" folder, and that if I deleted all the mails in the "All Mail" folder they would disappear from Inbox also?

gmail is an odd beast - if you delete a message from all your folders including Trash, it still exists in All Mail. Also, because of how gmail labels are map to imap folders, every message exists in at least two imap folders.

Peter Hoy said
2/. Also don't understand what you mean by 'subscribed' to All Mail folder - so far as I remember this was the default folder setup when first installed TB

Yes, All Mail folder is presented by default. But it isn't needed in Thunderbird for proper operation. To remove it from Thunderbird:

  • Unsubscribe - Right click on the gmail account and click "Subscribe", find the All Mail folder, uncheck it, then click OK. To free up the space on your disk, you then need to go to the directory
  • Free the space - Right click on the gmail account and pick Settings, then Server Settings, then at "Local Directory" click the Browse button. Under "[Gmail].sbd you should see two files All Mail and All Mail.msf. Shut down Thunderbird. Delete the two files.

Some background at https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-gmail, although not everything is well described there.

content: It may help to know your email domain. That is, some email providers store the sent message in a predefined folder regardless of your setting, such as sentmail. If you sent the folder to be sent, you could end up with two copies. Knowing your setting for the sent folder may also be helpful. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: A tip: when posting questions, it always helps to share some details. Now that I know you use gmail, I can advise that if you UNTICK saving the message in sent folder, that gmail does it anyway. That implies to me that you have it set to store the message, and that is causing you to have two copies. You can verify this by unticking the Sent folder setting, send a message, and then check the sent folder and the message should be there. See, you learned something today. :) Enjoy.
creator: davidsk

content: Gmail automatically copies sent messages to Sent Mail, so uncheck 'Place a copy in' in Account Settings, Copies & Folders. Unsubscribe Sent by right-clicking the account in the Folder Pane, Subscribe... In the same Subscribe window, unsubscribe the Drafts folder that appears near the top of the list and subscribe the Drafts folder under [Gmail], lower down. Set drafts to be saved in [Gmail]/Drafts in Copies & Folders, or Drafts on Local Folders if you don't need to access drafts on multiple devices.

content:
La domanda non è molto chiara. Di che collegamento parli? Cosa provi a fare per avviare Thunderbird? e cosa non funziona?

Più in generale, Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content: Make sure cookies are allowed in Thunderbird during the authentication. Also see https://support.mozilla.org/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20
creator: christ1

content:
I already had Cookies enabled. I even tried deleting the Cookies from accounts.google.com and trying again, same issue occurred.

creator: e.katowitz

content:
Also make sure you do not use a VPN.

Turn off your anti-virus software during the authentication attempt.

In general it is recommended to create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-do-i-find-my-profile

Are you running some sort of software like a web server, which is blocking TCP port 80 on localhost? This can also be anti-virus/security software blocking that port.

Start Thunderbird in troubleshooting mode. Does the problem go away?
creator: christ1

content: Thank you. I disabled my work's VPN and my local Web Server and that solved it.

content:
Here's a simple way, done with windows file explorer - click account settings - click to Local Folders pane - note the file location in the Local Directory line at bottom - exit thunderbird - IMPORTANT - in windows file explorer, copy (not move) that exact folder to the external drive - now, restart thunderbird - locate the local folders pane as before - click the local folders dropdown on bottom line and set to the new location. thunderbird will likely close and restart - check that all is well and that the Local Folders pane points as desired - you can now delete the Local Folders folder in the C drive.

REMEMBER: When you do backups or transfer to new PC,you need to stay aware that part of your account is not in the profile.
creator: davidsk

content:
Go to Outgoing Server (SMTP) in the account settings and make sure that all instances of SMTP servers for that gmail server name have an authentication method of oauth. Oauth pops up requests for re-authentication in web page sized windows, little dialogs asking for a password are a clear indicator of years out of date authentication settings.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Is your computer managed by your employer, school, or another organization?

Check the update debug log and other update files:

  1. Settings > General > Config Editor (https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/config-editor)
  2. Paste in app.update.log and set it to true
  3. Open the Console either with the hotkey Control+Shift+J (Command+Shift+J on macOS), or via Hamburger Menu->Tools->Developer Tools->Console
  4. Near the top, in the text field "Filter Output", enter AUS: to select just messages related to updates. Check that Logs is highlighted at "Errors Warnings Logs".
  5. In Settings' search field type or paste "updates", then click on the button "Update to xxx" or "Check for Updates"
  6. Once the update check has completed, copy the messages out of the Console and attach them here.
  7. In same area of Settings click the button "Show Update History" and screen shot it
  8. If the update process began and is being investigated, do Help > Troubleshooting Information to find "Update Folder", click "Open Folder" or "Show in Finder" and expand that directory to find last-update.log, last-update.log and backup-update.log and attach
creator: wsmwk

content:
If you are using the file send from the menu of word the result you get will depend on what version of word you are using.

I am lead to understand that newer versions of Word can send files that way using something other than outlook. Early versions relied entirely on Outlook.

If Thunderbird is a 64bit version and your office applications are 32 bit, you may also be suffering from this bug. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1879717
